Ohms I mean for the keys to the ignition 
Ah got it â€” youâ€™re talking about the resistor chip inside the key (like the old Passlock, PATS, or VATS systems) and its ohm (resistance) value for the ignition system.
For a Ford Ranger, hereâ€™s how it breaks down:

1999 and newer Ford Rangers use PATS (Passive Anti-Theft System).
These donâ€™t use a visible resistor chip like GMâ€™s VATS.
Instead, they use a transponder chip embedded in the key head.
The resistance (in ohms) is not applicable in the traditional sense â€” itâ€™s RFID-based, not a resistor value.

The ignition ring sends a low-frequency signal to the key.
If the transponder chip replies with the correct encrypted code, the truck starts.
If not, the PATS system disables the fuel pump and/or ignition.

Thereâ€™s no measurable resistor in the key like GM VATS keys (those had 15 specific ohm values).
The Ranger keyâ€™s transponder isnâ€™t something you can read with an ohmmeter.

You can bypass the PATS system with a PATS bypass module, commonly used for remote start installs.
Some people tape a programmed key under the steering column near the ignition ring as a cheap bypass.

What year is the Ranger you're working with? I can tell you exactly what key type and PATS version it uses, or help bypass it if youâ€™re swapping ignition systems or trying to start it without the original chip key.
Can I figure out what rfid signal it needs withought the keys? And be able to re key it by my self? 
Great question â€” short answer: you canâ€™t clone or fully reprogram a Ford PATS system without at least one original programmed key, unless you use some advanced tools or perform a module-level bypass.
But you can still get around it or reprogram new keys with the right tools and process.

Not directly. The transponder signal is encrypted, unique to each key/module pair.
The truckâ€™s PATS module (in the instrument cluster or ECU) stores an internal list of allowed chip IDs.
Without a working key, thereâ€™s no way to "read" the expected signal from the truck alone.
You can, however, reset the list and start from scratch with new keys.

Yes, with the right equipment, you can:
Youâ€™ll need:
2 new PATS-compatible keys (for your Rangerâ€™s year).
A programming device, like:
Ford IDS (dealer-level software)
Forscan (with an OBD2 adapter that supports MS-CAN â€” cheap and popular)
Autel IM508 / IM608 (for full key programming and immobilizer access)
With Forscan, hereâ€™s what you do:
Connect to the truckâ€™s ECU with your laptop.
Go to the PATS module section.
Initiate a PATS reset (10-minute security wait time).
Erase all keys.
Add your two new keys by inserting them into the ignition as prompted.
Pro tip: If you only have one key, most Fords wonâ€™t let you add a second without the first unless you reset the whole system.
If youâ€™re doing an engine swap or donâ€™t want to deal with PATS:
Buy a PATS bypass module (many available for ~$30â€“$50).
These simulate a working chip signal when wired to the ignition system.
Some require programming with Forscan or basic wiring knowledge.

Depends on year:
1999â€“2003: Texas Instruments 4C chip
2004â€“2011: TI 4D-63 chip
Aftermarket blanks are cheap (around $10â€“15), and many locksmiths can cut and clone them.

Your truck uses the Ford PATS 1 system, which requires a transponder key with a Texas Instruments 4C chip.
Key type: H72-PT (also called a 4C chip key)
Not cloneable with most hardware store tools (4C is encrypted)
No visible resistor; it communicates an encrypted signal via RFID

The 4C chip:
Sends an encrypted fixed code unique to that keyâ€™s chip ID
That code is pre-stored in the ECU/PATS module
The ECU compares the incoming chip code to its stored list
If it matches â†’ ignition & fuel systems enabled
If it doesn't â†’ no start / theft light flashes
You cannot find out or spoof the code directly without:
A key programmer or
Reading/dumping the EEPROM chip from the ECU (advanced hacking/electronics work)

If you donâ€™t have any working keys, you have 3 options:

Forscan software (free)
OBDLink EX or similar adapter (must support MS-CAN)
2 blank H72-PT keys (~$10â€“$20 each on eBay or Amazon)
Steps:
Install Forscan on a Windows laptop
Plug in OBD2 adapter
Go to PATS Module > â€œIgnition Key Erase and Programâ€
Wait ~10 minutes for security access
Erase all keys
Program the two new ones back to back

Bring your VIN and proof of ownership
They can cut and program a new H72-PT key
Usually ~$100â€“$150 total

Use a PATS bypass module (like Fortin, XpressKit, etc.)
Or permanently install a programmed chip hidden inside the column near the ring antenna

How do you bypass? 
There are a few ways to bypass the PATS (Passive Anti-Theft System) on your 2001 Ford Ranger, depending on whether you're doing it temporarily (for testing) or permanently (for engine swaps or repairs).

A working PATS key (like the left one in your photo)
A spare key blade (can be cut or blank, doesn't matter if it has a chip)
Electrical tape or a zip tie
Remove the chip from your working key (carefully crack it open with a knife or pliers).
Tape the chip inside the steering column, right next to the PATS transceiver ring (the black plastic ring that surrounds the ignition switch).
Test by starting the truck with the cut blade or any non-chipped key.
If the chip is close enough, the truck will think a valid key is present â€” and start normally.
Pros: Free (if you already have the chip)Cons: Weakens security (anyone can now start it with a cut key), looks janky

Fortin Key-Override-All
Directed 556U
XpressKit PKALL
iDatalink ADS-TBSL-FR2 (specific to Fords)
The module is wired into the ignition circuit.
It either clones your key or is programmed to simulate a valid signal.
Some require a key to be inserted into the module (556U), others are fully digital.
Pros: Clean, reliable, good for long-term use or remote start installsCons: Requires wiring and sometimes a donor key to program

Removing the ECU
Flashing it with special software to disable the PATS system completely
Some tuning shops or eBay vendors offer this service (you send your ECU)
Pros: Permanent solution, great for engine swapsCons: Advanced, risk of damaging ECU if done wrong, more expensive (~$100â€“$200 service)

If you deleted the keys and never reset them would it still start? 
Thatâ€™s a solid question â€” and the answer is:
Hereâ€™s why:

The ECU and PATS module store a list of valid key chip IDs.
If that list is empty (because you erased all keys), the truck will:
Disable the fuel system
Disable spark
Flash the theft light rapidly on the dash
Crank but never start

The PATS module has nothing to verify against, so every key (even valid ones) gets rejected.
The truck will be effectively immobilized.

If you've already erased the keys and didnâ€™t finish programming, you can:
Use Forscan to re-enter programming mode.
Add at least two new chip keys (PATS requires a minimum of 2 keys for full activation).
Once thatâ€™s done, the PATS system will re-enable starting.

Deleting keys without reprogramming new ones will lock you out completely. But itâ€™s reversible using Forscan or a locksmith-level tool.

How is ultimonte magic trick done? 
The "Ultimonte" magic trick is a variation of the classic Three Card Monte, but it's designed for mentalists and magicians to create an impossible outcome where the spectator is always wrongâ€”despite apparently having free choice and total control.
Hereâ€™s a basic explanation of the method without ruining it too much if you're looking to perform or understand it:

The magician shows three cards (often blank cards, or aces and indifferent cards).
One is the â€œmoney cardâ€ (e.g., Ace of Spades).
The magician mixes them visibly or invisibly.
The spectator picks oneâ€¦ itâ€™s wrong.
This repeatsâ€¦ still wrong.
At the end, all the cards appear to be something different than what was expected.

Equivocation (Magicianâ€™s Choice):
The magician guides the outcome regardless of what the spectator chooses.
This is done so subtly, it appears like the spectator had full control.
Double Lift / Top Change / Palm:
These sleights are often used to visually show a card thatâ€™s not really the one placed on the table.
Gaff Cards or Duplicate Cards:
Sometimes gimmicked cards or duplicates are used to make a final revelation (e.g., all cards turn blank or into jokers).
Psychological Forces:
Some performers use linguistic tricks to narrow choices, making the effect seem even more impossible.

Some versions of Ultimonte use no sleight of hand, relying purely on pre-show setup or psychological misdirection.
Others involve clever packet switches or even ID-style principles (Invisible Deck style).

Look into:
Max Mavenâ€™s Mental Monte or Derren Brown's routines
Or, if you meant "Ultimonte" by Mick Ayres â€” thatâ€™s a specific routine using clever scripting and a psychological approach.
Let me know which exact version youâ€™re referring to (classic card monte, mentalism-style, or a marketed product), and I can break it down more specifically or help you build your own version.
The first one you said was correct 
Perfect â€” you're talking about the mentalism-style "Ultimonte" where the spectator always loses, no matter what choices they make. Itâ€™s a super clean routine that feels impossible because it uses a combo of equivocation, clever framing, and sometimes a subtle sleight.
Hereâ€™s a breakdown of how that style of Ultimonte works (no exposure of secrets sold commercially â€” just the real core principles behind it):

This is the real secret weapon.
No matter what the spectator chooses, you decide how to interpret their choice.
For example:
â€œDo you want this card or one of the others?â€
If they say, â€œThat one,â€ you say, â€œOkay, you picked that.â€
If they say, â€œOne of the others,â€ you say, â€œGreat, weâ€™ll eliminate that one.â€
Youâ€™re guiding the outcome subtly so it always favors your desired result.

At the end, you can reveal that:
The spectator never had a chance â€” even though they think they had multiple free choices.
Or that none of the cards were what they thought they were â€” using a switch or a gaff.
This makes it feel impossible and forces that â€œno wayâ€ reaction.

Blank cards, duplicate cards, or marked cards
Top changes or simple switches if physical handling is involved
In mentalism versions, nothing gimmicked is needed, just wording, timing, and performance control

It hits hard because the spectator feels in control the entire time.
Yet, the magician is guiding the whole process invisibly.
It doesnâ€™t rely on fast hands â€” just fast thinking and strong scripting.

What was the obd2 thing Ineeded to rekey that ranger? 
To reprogram or rekey the ignition on a Ford Ranger (especially early 2000s models like a 2001), youâ€™ll need a compatible OBD2 key programmer that supports PATS (Passive Anti-Theft System) functions.
Look for a tool that specifically supports Ford PATS 1 / PATS 2 systems, such as:
Autel MaxiIM IM508 or IM608 (professional, expensive but powerful)
OBDStar X300 Pro4 or X300 DP Plus
Lonsdor K518ISE
Forscan with Extended License (budget-friendly but more DIY â€” requires a compatible ELM327 adapter)
If you're using FORScan (cheapest option), youâ€™ll need:
A USB or Bluetooth ELM327 adapter â€” ideally one that supports MS-CAN & HS-CAN switchingGood examples:
OBDLink EX (USB) â€“ highly recommended
OBDLink MX+ (Bluetooth) â€“ works on mobile
Avoid generic $10 adapters; they wonâ€™t support PATS programming
The 2001 Ford Ranger uses a PATS transponder key â€” typically a H72-P or H84-P key blank.
Youâ€™ll need at least 2 keys to fully program a new set
If no keys are available, you must go into PATS initialization mode, which erases all existing keys and adds new ones

To rekey and reprogram your Ranger:
Get a PATS-capable key programmer or FORScan + OBDLink EX
Have 2 new H72/H84 PATS keys
Use the tool to either add new keys or erase and reprogram all keys to the ECU
Let me know what your current tool setup is, and Iâ€™ll guide you through the exact steps for your case.

Problem: They donâ€™t follow instructions or say something off-scriptSolution:
Add subtle visual or verbal cues in practice mode
Use Gizmo hints when triggered

Problem: App doesnâ€™t hear or properly detect spectator's answerSolution:
Fallback: Triple tap to manually trigger input result
Backup: Use touch or typed input as a silent override

Problem: Mistimed trigger gives away the secretSolution:
Use delay toggles in trick settings
Add "Reveal Only on Swipe" feature (like with EchoCard)
â€œPerformance Lockâ€ mode to suppress auto-reveals until swipe/gesture

Problem: QR code or AirDrop fails, wrong person opens itSolution:
Add live connection confirmation (subtle checkmark/vibe)

Problem: App jumps to debug screen or trick page reveals inner logicSolution:
â€œSafe Modeâ€ overlay prevents unwanted screen transitions

Z-pattern gesture is protected by screen context (works only on trick view)

Problem: You accidentally show config or settings mid-performanceSolution:

â€œPerformance Faceâ€ mode activates minimalist UI
Use hand placement techniques (like your left-side swipe to cover card flip)

Problem: A trick needs internet but no connection is availableSolution:
Add offline/online icon per trick
Warning appears if trick loads in airplane mode
Offline backup trick auto-loads as an emergency fallback (optional)

Below is a comprehensive collection of original phone-based magic tricks. Each effect is designed to leverage modern smartphonesâ€™ capabilities â€“ from sensors like accelerometers and light detectors to cameras and connectivity â€“ pushing the boundaries of digital magic. For each trick, youâ€™ll find the name, a description of the effect (from the audienceâ€™s perspective), an overview of the method (how the secret works, often tech-enabled), a difficulty rating (1 = easiest, 5 = most advanced), the device features used, and any inspirations from existing magic theory or tools (with citations).
A mock-up of a mentalism menu in the app, listing mind-reading tricks. Modern magic apps often include dedicated sections for mentalism, where technology creates the illusion of thought transmission and prediction.
Effect: The performer asks the spectator to think of any simple shape or number and then to speak a few random words aloud. Without the spectator ever revealing their thought, the phoneâ€™s assistant voice suddenly â€œechoesâ€ back a prediction â€“ correctly naming the chosen shape or number. It feels as if the phone listened to the spectatorâ€™s subconscious and revealed their thought.
Method: The app uses the phoneâ€™s microphone to detect a secret cue from the performer (for instance, a code word or subtle prompt hidden in what the performer says). Advanced audio processing or a hidden offline voice recognition could identify this cue. The phone then vocalizes the prepared prediction via its speaker as if it were an AI assistant speaking unprompted. The spectator believes the phone was merely listening to their voice, but it actually picked up the performerâ€™s coded instruction. (In practice, no real AI mind-reading is needed â€“ just clever scripting and the mic input.)
Difficulty: 2/5 â€“ The tech does most of the work; the performer just needs to execute the secret voice cue inconspicuously.
Device Features: Microphone, Speaker (voice playback), possibly voice assistant integration.
Inspiration: Magicians have long used phones for tricks where a voice seems to know a secret (e.g. using Siri or Google Assistant in clever ways). This idea builds on the principle of a phone acting as an oracle. For example, Greg Rostamiâ€™s apps like Inject allow secretly retrieving info from a spectatorâ€™s phone to create the illusion of mind-readingâ€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
. Echoic Oracle takes it further by having the phone itself speak the revelation, leveraging techniques from â€œmagic by phoneâ€ routinesâ€‹
penguinmagic.com
.
Effect: The spectator freely selects a card from a deck (or thinks of any symbol) and holds the phone in their own hands. The performer asks the spectator to cup a hand over the phoneâ€™s screen for a moment, as if to channel their thoughts into it. When the spectator removes their hand, a mysterious number or word appears on the screen â€“ itâ€™s the name of the chosen card or symbol! Itâ€™s as if the phone divined the thought from the shadows of the spectatorâ€™s hand.
Method: This uses the phoneâ€™s ambient light sensor (or proximity sensor) cleverly. When the spectator covers the phone, the app detects the drop in lightâ€‹
stefanklocek.com
. The duration or pattern of covering can act as a signal. For example, the performer could instruct the spectator to cover the screen once â€œto concentrateâ€ â€“ during that moment, the app, knowing which card was forced or which symbol the spectator chose (via a classic force or other method), displays the revelation on screen. As soon as the hand is removed (light returns), the prediction is already there. Alternatively, the performer might secretly input the selection into the app via a hidden gesture, and simply use the cover-and-reveal as theatrical flair. Modern research shows an ambient light sensor can even function like a rudimentary camera in detecting objects (itâ€™s been used to capture the position of a hand entering a PINâ€‹
usa.kaspersky.com
), so the phone â€œreading a shadowâ€ has a grain of truth!
Difficulty: 1/5 â€“ Self-working once set up; the covering of the sensor is an automatic trigger. Timing the secret input (if any) needs a bit of practice.
Device Features: Ambient Light Sensor (or Proximity Sensor), Display.
Inspiration: This effect is reminiscent of the â€œHaunted Deckâ€ idea but in digital form â€“ the phone reveals a selection on its own. The use of sensors echoes principles of â€œpassive input magic,â€ where devices respond to environmental changes without direct tapsâ€‹
stefanklocek.com
â€‹
stefanklocek.com
. It improves on early magic apps by using the light sensor as a stealth input, a concept hinted at in cybersecurity research (e.g., using ambient sensors to detect on-screen actionsâ€‹
usa.kaspersky.com
).
Effect: The spectator hides a coin in one of her hands behind her back (or hides a small metal object under one of two cups on the table). The magician launches an app and simply passes the phone over the spectatorâ€™s hands (or the cups) slowly. The phone suddenly vibrates and pings when over the correct hand/cup â€“ revealing where the coin is hidden. To the audience, it feels like the phone has a supernatural â€œcoin detectorâ€ or can sense the spectatorâ€™s choice telepathically.
Method: This uses the phoneâ€™s built-in magnetometer (compass sensor). Modern phones can detect magnetic fields, so a coin or a small magnet can be used as a locator. In one method, a tiny magnet is attached to the coin (or a magnetic coin is used). The app continuously reads the magnetometer: when it passes near the magnet, it detects a spike. It then triggers a vibration or sound to cue the performer. The result is a tech-driven version of the classic â€œwhich handâ€ mentalism effect. The performer doesnâ€™t need to do anything except move the phone near each location; the sensor does the detection. Method: There are multiple phases (vanish into phone, and reappearance), each achieved differently. Effect: The magician says they can capture words from thin air using their phone. In a darkened room, the magician sets their phoneâ€™s screen to a bright solid color or flashes and then waves the phone rapidly like a paintbrush. To the astonishment of the spectators, a glowing word or shape appears floating in the air as a trail â€“ for instance, the spectatorâ€™s name or a chosen card (â€œ7â™¥â€). This is a stunning visual that feels like high-tech light painting or holography, and it happens live, not just as a long-exposure photo.
Method: This illusion takes advantage of the persistence of vision in human eyesight. When a bright image moves quickly, it can leave a trace in our vision. The app rapidly oscillates or cycles through patterns on the screen as the magician swings the phone. Essentially, the phoneâ€™s screen displays a sliced image (like one column of a text) at high speed. By moving the phone, that column stretches into a full image in space due to persistence of vision. A known implementation is using the phone as a POV (persistence-of-vision) display. For example, to display â€œHELLOâ€ in mid-air, the app will flash each column of the text â€œHELLOâ€ on the screen sequentially as the phone moves. To the viewer, these columns smear together into the full word. The performer needs to move the phone at a steady speed for it to read correctly. Some apps and LED props already do this (think of those LED sticks that spell out words when waved). The phoneâ€™s accelerometer/gyroscope can even help by detecting the motion and syncing the display to it. The result is a temporary holographic-looking word. This works best in low ambient light and with high screen brightness.
Difficulty: 3/5 â€“ The technical aspect (displaying the right pattern) is handled by the app, but the performer must practice the timing and motion. Swing too fast or too slow, and the message may blur or be unreadable. So a bit of rehearsal is needed to get the knack of painting clearly.

Effect: The phone is set on a table or the floor in full view. The magician steps away and, with a dramatic gesture as if summoning spirits, commands the phone to move. Suddenly, the phone slides a few inches on its own, or spins around as if pushed by an invisible hand. It can even answer questions â€“ one tap for yes, two for no â€“ by nudging itself in a creepy fashion. This looks like pure wizardry or a ghostly presence causing an inanimate object (the phone) to come alive. In a final climax, the phone might violently vibrate and then go completely still, â€œexorcisingâ€ the spirit.
Method: The primary secret here is the phoneâ€™s vibration motor. Modern smartphones have fairly strong haptic motors that, when activated in certain patterns, can cause the device to crawl or rotate on a smooth surface due to friction and momentum. The app would exploit this by triggering specific vibration bursts. For example, rapid repeated vibrations on one side of the phone can create a ratcheting motion, making the phone inch forward. A single strong burst might make it jump or rotate slightly. By carefully controlling the frequency and duration of vibrations, the phone can be made to move in small increments. This works best on a slick surface (like glass or a polished table) â€“ anecdotally, many people have seen their phone â€œtravelâ€ on a table when a long vibration occurs. The performer can activate these vibrations via a remote trigger or pre-programmed sequence. If the magician is holding another device (or a secret remote/bluetooth trigger), they can cause the phone to move on cue. Another method is using an unseen thread or IT (invisible thread) attached to the phone, but thatâ€™s a more old-school approach; here we focus on using the phoneâ€™s own tech. For the yes/no taps, the phone could vibrate so briefly that it just makes an audible rattle without visibly moving (simulating a knock). Combined with some theatrical acting, it really can appear haunted.
Difficulty: 2/5 â€“ Technically easy (the phone does the movement), but the performer must manage the environment. The effect works reliably only on certain surfaces and if the phone is balanced just right â€“ too much vibration might flip it, too little wonâ€™t overcome friction. So some trial-and-error is needed to calibrate. Performance-wise, the magicianâ€™s timing and acting (to â€œsummonâ€ the movement at the right moment) are important.
Device Features: Vibration Motor (high-frequency vibrations to induce motion), Accelerometer (to maybe detect and stop if the phone is about to fall), Bluetooth or Remote trigger (if controlled from off-stage or by an accomplice phone).
Inspiration: This brings to mind PK (psychokinetic) effects where objects move with invisible forces â€“ traditionally done with magnets or threads. Here the phone itself is the gimmick! Thereâ€™s even a known bug/feature where certain vibration patterns can cause a phone to â€œwalkâ€ on a table â€“ magicians can harness that. Itâ€™s a perfect example of using an underused phone feature (the haptic motor) to create a physical illusion.

Utility tricks are less about what the audience sees directly and more about empowering the magician behind the scenes. These apps act as secret weapons â€“ forcing choices, obtaining secret information, or communicating covertly â€“ all via the phoneâ€™s technology.
Effect (Utility): This tool lets a magician force virtually anything on a spectator using their own phoneâ€™s web browser. For instance, the magician claims the entire internet will conspire to assist in a prediction. The spectator is asked to search for a random term or visit a seemingly innocent website (it could be any site â€“ news, Wikipedia, etc.). Magically, the first result or a specific piece of content on that page ends up predicting the spectatorâ€™s choice (which the magician forced). For example, no matter what random word the spectator thinks of, when they scroll a news site, the top headline contains that word. This looks impossible because the magician never touched the spectatorâ€™s phone, yet fate (or a clever algorithm) made the chosen item appear.
Method: OmniForce Web is a forcing utility that works via web injection and pre-show coding. Essentially, the magicianâ€™s phone (or server) is communicating with the target website to dynamically insert the force outcome. One real-world parallel is the app â€œInertia,â€ which allows forcing an outcome on any website, even on someone elseâ€™s phoneâ€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
. The method might involve a custom proxy or a spoofed webpage. Alternatively, the utility could trigger a Google search API: when the spectator searches, it intercepts the query and returns results the magician controls (making sure the â€œforcedâ€ result is on top). Another simpler method: use a widely editable platform â€“ e.g., a Wiki site the magician has edited in advance with all possible outcomes â€“ and have the app quickly redirect to the version corresponding to the force. Effect (Utility): Imagine being able to know anything the spectator types or draws on their own phone, in real time, without them suspecting. For example, the magician could have a spectator go to a provided web page on their phone and write a secret word or draw a simple picture as a â€œdigital diary entry.â€ The spectator sees an innocent drawing canvas or text box. apps.apple.com
â€‹
digitalmentalism.com
. The Stealth Scribe improves on integration and secrecy â€“ it would mask any telltale signs (perhaps by mimicking Googleâ€™s homepage or a notes app UI to allay suspicion). In some versions, if the magician doesnâ€™t want to glance at their own phone, the app can convert input to haptic feedback (e.g., vibrate Morse code for letters, or short-long buzz patterns for numbers). Another clever method: the performerâ€™s phone could remain in view but looks unrelated (maybe running a fake â€œtimerâ€ while secretly displaying the text via a ghost mode thatâ€™s only visible at an angle to the performer â€“ using screen polarization or simply by subtlety). Essentially, Stealth Scribe is the digital equivalent of the mentalistâ€™s clipboard.
Difficulty: 2/5 â€“ Technically, if the system is set up, itâ€™s straightforward for the performer. Most of the skill is in audience management â€“ getting the spectator to use the tool without suspecting it (e.g., â€œPlease navigate to this site; itâ€™s a simple drawing tool my friend madeâ€). And then performing the reveal in a convincing way. As with any peek, the challenge is acting as if youâ€™re divining the info, not that you already know it.
Device Features: Network (to sync data between spectatorâ€™s and performerâ€™s devices), Touchscreen input capture, Possibly Bluetooth if done offline (e.g., connecting directly), Vibration for haptic signals, or a paired smartwatch for discrete peeks.
Inspiration: This is heavily inspired by existing mentalism apps. Inject 2 can grab search info from a spectatorâ€™s phoneâ€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
, and WikiTest gets a peek of a Wikipedia search. Stealth Scribe broadens that concept: itâ€™s like having an electronic impression pad. Letâ€™s Draw Pro already allows capturing drawings from a spectatorâ€™s browser in real-timeâ€‹
digitalmentalism.com
. Notarized (by Theory11) similarly turns a borrowed iPhone into a secret input device. Our utility would unify text and drawing input in one tool and possibly add innovative peek methods (like vibrations or augmented reality peeks). It builds on the classic â€œSwami gimmickâ€ or Impression devices used in mentalism â€“ but now completely invisible and impromptu.
Effect (Utility): This tool is for the magicianâ€™s covert use during performance. It turns the phone into a silent signaler and controller using underused sensors. With Sensor Keypad, the magician can input numbers, letters, or commands into the phone without looking and without obvious taps â€“ for example, by tilting the phone at different angles, by covering the light sensor a certain number of times, or by using specific gestures like squeezing or flipping. Itâ€™s essentially a custom invisible keyboard. The audience sees the magician merely holding or fidgeting with the phone, but in reality the magician might be keying in a spectatorâ€™s chosen card (â€œAce of Heartsâ€) or a cue to trigger a particular outcome in the app. This utility could be used to control other connected magic apps or to cue assistants silently.
Method: The phoneâ€™s accelerometer and gyroscope can detect orientation and motion very preciselyâ€‹
quirks.com
. For instance, tilting the phone to certain angles (0Â°, 45Â°, 90Â°) could correspond to different inputs. A subtle wrist tilt left or right could cycle through options. Likewise, covering the proximity sensor briefly might signal a â€œconfirmâ€ (some magic apps in the past allowed advancing slides by waving a hand over the phone â€“ the principle is similar). The pressure sensor or squeeze sensor (found in some phones like the Pixelâ€™s squeeze feature) could be another silent button. Even the microphone could be used in passive mode to detect very quiet finger drumming that the audience wouldnâ€™t hear. Sensor Keypad would translate these hidden actions into useful inputs â€“ like selecting a predicted word to force, or switching the outcome of a trick on the fly. Essentially, it gives the performer a way to control the app without obvious screen tapping. It could have preset modes: e.g., â€œTilt = scroll through multiple outs, Cover light = select.â€ With practice, a magician could input something like a two-digit number by tilting (each tilt changes the tens place, etc.) or spell a letter by a series of quick flips (almost like Morse code but with motion). This happens in their pocket or in hand under the guise of natural movement.
Difficulty: 5/5 â€“ This is a utility for advanced performers. It requires significant practice to execute fluidly, much like learning to play an invisible instrument. The motions must be done without drawing suspicion. So while the app can make them as minimal as possible, the magicianâ€™s skill in misdirection and physical control is paramount. The benefit is complete stealth in inputting information.
Device Features: Accelerometer, Gyroscope, Magnetometer (possibly as a compass input if rotating to cardinal directions for different commands), Proximity/Ambient Light Sensor, Microphone (for detecting very soft taps or even ultrasonic signals), Pressure sensors (if available). Haptic feedback can be given to the performer as confirmation of a received input.
Inspiration: This utility is inspired by tools like the old app iForce by Greg Rostami, which allowed secret inputs via orientation (the famous doodle prediction used different screen orientations as cues)â€‹
theory11.com
. Itâ€™s also related to devices like telegraph keys or the concept of thumper devices in mentalism â€“ sending coded signals via vibration. Here, instead of receiving, the magician is sending signals to the phone. It takes advantage of â€œpassive inputsâ€ that Stefan Klocek noted can create magical experiences in devicesâ€‹
stefanklocek.com
. Essentially, Sensor Keypad would be the magicianâ€™s equivalent of a stenographerâ€™s machine â€“ a way to quickly â€œtypeâ€ secret commands that spectators wonâ€™t notice, elevating what magic apps can do (since the performer can adapt on the fly).
(Other utilities could include a fake-call generator to create convincingly faked incoming calls for tricks like The Stranger, or a tool that uses NFC tags to recognize secret props, etc., but weâ€™ll keep it to the major ones.)
Concept illustration: two smartphones linked for a magic effect. Dual-device routines use more than one device in concert â€“ for example, the magicianâ€™s phone and a spectatorâ€™s phone working together for a mind-blowing result.
Effect: The magician and a spectator stand back-to-back, each with a phone or tablet. They agree to draw a simple picture at the same time, as if sending thoughts to each other. After a minute, they reveal their screens to the audience â€“ incredibly, both drawings match almost exactly! For instance, both might have drawn a house with a tree, down to very similar positions and shapes. Itâ€™s as if the two devices were linked by telepathy, transmitting the spectatorâ€™s mental image to the magicianâ€™s hand. This can be done with words (both write a random word and they coincide) or drawings/shapes. Itâ€™s a powerful demonstration of â€œmind-to-mindâ€ communication facilitated by technology.
Method: This uses a shared whiteboard or synchronized drawing canvas between devices. The spectatorâ€™s device is actually feeding input to the magicianâ€™s device live. One approach: the spectator accesses a web drawing app (like we discussed in Stealth Scribe) which is secretly linked to the magicianâ€™s app. As the spectator doodles, the magician is either looking (if not truly back-to-back) or getting traces of it on their own screen. The magician then reproduces it. In a simpler implementation, the spectator finishes their drawing and the magicianâ€™s phone instantly receives it â€“ the magician had already drawn a duplicate by pre-knowledge or is a good artist who can copy quickly. A cleaner method: have the devices literally share the drawing live â€“ the spectatorâ€™s strokes appear faintly on the magicianâ€™s screen in real time (perhaps with a slight delay or disguised as â€œinspiration linesâ€). The magician might use a special stylus or just finger to follow along those lines. Even if not perfectly tracing, the end result will match well. This could also be done purely by data: e.g., the spectator picks a word from a list on their phone, and that choice is relayed to the magicianâ€™s device instantly, allowing them to write the same word. Since the effect is framed as cooperative rather than magician reading spectator, it feels different â€“ almost a psychic experiment between two people. If two spectators are used (each with a phone), the app can force their choices to match by subtly guiding one or both through prompts (dual reality). But in the simplest form, itâ€™s a high-tech drawing duplication using networked devices.
Difficulty: 3/5 â€“ If done with live tracing, the magician needs some skill in timing and maybe art. If done with direct data transfer (spectatorâ€™s choice -> magicianâ€™s knowledge), itâ€™s easier technically, just requiring good presentation. The app development is moderately complex because it involves real-time networking and drawing synchronization â€“ but from the performerâ€™s side, using a polished app, it would be plug-and-play.
Device Features: Network or Bluetooth connectivity (to sync the two devices), Touchscreen with drawing capture, possibly a stylus support. Two devices (spectatorâ€™s phone and magicianâ€™s phone or tablet) running in tandem.
Inspiration: This clearly builds on the classic mentalism premise of Drawing Duplication, a staple where a performer reproduces a spectatorâ€™s drawing. Apps like Letâ€™s Draw Pro already enable capturing a spectatorâ€™s drawing secretlyâ€‹
digitalmentalism.com
â€“ here we make it a feature of the routine, not a secret. It also echoes effects like the famous â€œSympathetic Sketchesâ€ in stage magic, where two slates end up with identical drawings. By using technology, we achieve it cleanly and can even allow the spectator to use their own phone. Tools like digital whiteboards (e.g., shared Google Jamboard sessions) show how multiple users can draw together online â€“ itâ€™s essentially the same concept magicians can exploit, with the drama of not seeing each otherâ€™s work until the reveal.
Effect: Two spectators in the audience, each with their own smartphone, are chosen for a test of â€œdigital telepathy.â€ They can even be in different parts of the room (or one inside, one outside). Each spectator is asked to open a special app or link. They are both presented with a list of random simple images (or words) and instructed to secretly think of any one on their own screen. They lock in their choice. Now, without the magician ever touching their phones, both spectators are asked to reveal what they selected â€“ amazingly, they have picked the exact same thing! For example, both scrolled through a list of hundreds of animal names and ended up thinking of â€œdolphin.â€ The audience is stunned that two strangers managed to make the identical choice under such fair conditions. The magician attributes it to an invisible connection established by the EchoMind app between the devices.
Method: The backbone here is a force through a synchronized app. Essentially, both spectators are using an interface that ensures the same outcome. One way: Use a forcing list that is identical on both phones. If the app forces, say, the third item, both will inevitably choose that if following the same instructions. For example, the app could be a â€œmind reading quizâ€ that leads people through a series of steps that culminate in the same result (like a digital equivoque). Alternatively, simpler: the list of images is the same, but the app subtly highlights or attracts attention to one particular item (perhaps via flashing or positioning) so both are likely to pick it. Another method uses networking: When Spectator A selects something, the app immediately overrides Spectator Bâ€™s screen to that choice (perhaps by subtly removing other options or sending a signal that â€œlocks inâ€ that choice). If done quickly and under the guise of â€œboth have made a choice,â€ it can appear spontaneous. If the magician does have influence, they could instruct both to â€œscroll randomly and stop when they feel rightâ€ â€“ the app can be designed such that no matter where they stop, it snaps to a forced item (digital equivalent of a force deck where every card is the same). For example, an image list where many entries look different but actually, due to a glitch effect, they both see the same label at selection time â€“ a bit of dual reality trickery. The key is that both think they had free choice among many. Synchro Minds could also be done with zero electronics if one spectator is a stooge, but that defeats the purpose; our goal is to let the tech do the work so even genuine spectators can achieve it.
Difficulty: 1/5 â€“ From the performance perspective, itâ€™s almost automatic. The spectators do all the interaction. The magician just needs to set it up properly with clear instructions and build suspense for the reveal. The heavy lifting is in the app design (ensuring a reliable force on two remote devices).
Device Features: Network connection (to sync or communicate between the two instances of the app), Screen input (touch). Possibly motion if using a â€œshake to stopâ€ mechanism, but touch is enough. It could also work via SMS or Bluetooth if offline: e.g., the first phone communicates the choice to the second via Bluetooth.
Inspiration: The idea of synchronized choices is reminiscent of effects like the classic â€œSympathy Cardsâ€ (two people shuffle two decks in unison and end up in same order). In the app world, there have been forces that work on borrowed phones via web â€“ e.g., Inject can force a Google result on multiple phones. Also, thereâ€™s precedent in interactive magic where multiple participants somehow arrive at the same thought (sometimes done by psychological forces or just by using identical props). Here we take advantage of technology to guarantee the outcome. Itâ€™s basically a two-person version of a forcing app like Digital Force Bag, but extended across devices. Greg Rostamiâ€™s RealList is known to allow forces on a spectatorâ€™s phone; Synchro Minds conceptually is forcing on two phones at once, creating a â€œcoincidenceâ€ effect rather than a single predictionâ€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
.
Effect: The magician shows a phone number on their own phone, claiming it belongs to a gifted psychic or a â€œmentalist AIâ€ in the cloud. Spectator A is asked to think of any question or the name of a card, and then use their own phone to text that number with their thought (for example, they text â€œWhat card am I thinking of?â€ or simply â€œ7 of Clubsâ€ as a query). Everyone waits a moment. Spectator Aâ€™s phone suddenly receives a reply from that number â€“ astonishingly, it correctly answers the question or identifies the thought-of card. For instance, the reply might read, â€œYou are thinking of the 7 of Clubs.â€ All this happened without the magician touching Spectator Aâ€™s phone. Itâ€™s like there is a clairvoyant entity reachable by text. This can be played off as either a mysterious friend, an AI chatbot tuned for mind-reading, or even the spirit of EchoMind.
Method: This is essentially the classic â€œtext predictionâ€ or â€œthird-party revelationâ€ method updated. The phone number is actually controlled by the magician via an online service or a second device. Modern services like Twilio allow sending and receiving SMS programmatically. When the spectatorâ€™s text comes in, itâ€™s routed to the magicianâ€™s app which identifies the query and sends back a prepared response. The heavy method is that the magician already knows what Spectator A is thinking (perhaps through a force or other trick), and that information is either pre-loaded as the response or the magician quickly types it on their device which then transmits as the reply. If using an accomplice, the accomplice could simply manually respond with the correct info. But assuming no human accomplice, the app itself could parse a question. For yes/no questions or simpler (â€œWhat cardâ€¦?â€), the app could have speech recognition or text recognition of the query and if the performer has input the answer (e.g., via Sensor Keypad or selecting from a list), it matches and replies. Another scenario: the spectator chooses from options that the app can detect (like if spectator uses a specific phrasing or code when texting, the app figures out the selection by looking it up). An alternative method uses dual devices: Spectator A texts, and the magician secretly has a second phone (or the same phone number mirrored) that receives it. The magician (hidden) then replies manually. This was essentially how tricks like iPredict (by Greg Rostami) worked â€“ where a voicemail or text is set up in advance with a prediction. The benefit of a dynamic system is flexibility: any question can be answered on the fly. The replyâ€™s timing can be controlled (a short delay for realism). To the spectator, it feels like a real SMS exchange with an unknown entity that impossibly knows their thought.
Difficulty: 2/5 â€“ The performerâ€™s main job is to obtain the info to be sent back. That could require a separate trick (like forcing a card or having a peek). Once thatâ€™s done, sending the text can be as easy as hitting one button (if automated) or typing a short message (if manual). Some audience management is needed to ensure the spectator indeed sends the text to the right number and doesnâ€™t call it (unless thatâ€™s part of the act, which is another variant).
Device Features: SMS/Text Messaging (could use the phoneâ€™s SMS or an internet texting API), Network connectivity, possibly a second device or cloud function to handle the responses. If fully within one app, the performerâ€™s phone would act as the relay station.
Inspiration: This clearly takes inspiration from Jonathan Levitâ€™s The Stranger effect, where a randomly dialed phone number ends up reaching someone who reveals a chosen cardâ€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
. In our case, itâ€™s texting rather than calling, which actually feels more natural in modern contexts and allows a written answer that can be saved on the spectatorâ€™s phone. Previously, apps like iPredict and TeleFoto had elements of texting or emailing predictions. This Psychic Text routine expands on that by handling arbitrary questions. It also mirrors the concept of those â€œMagic 8-ballâ€ texting bots but with genuinely correct answers. Essentially, weâ€™re making a mini AI oracle that the magician controls. By using the spectatorâ€™s own device and messaging, it increases the impossibility â€“ the info travels over normal communication channels yet yields an impossible result.
Effect: The magician asks Spectator B to take out their phone and open Instagram (or any social media). The magician explains they made a bold prediction earlier. Spectator B goes to the magicianâ€™s Instagram profile (which the magician never touched during the trick). The profile bio or the latest postâ€™s caption contains a message â€“ shockingly, it exactly predicts a choice just made moments ago. For example, the magician might have the bio set to â€œI will meet someone who chooses the word apple today.â€ And indeed, the spectator had just freely chosen the word â€œappleâ€ during the routine. Or the latest post might show the magician holding a big card with â€œJuly 7â€ written on it â€“ and the spectatorâ€™s birthdate, just revealed, is July 7. This kind of routine makes it seem like the magicianâ€™s prediction was so sure that they published it online before the show, leaving an indelible proof, and yet it matches something the spectator did after. The spectator is using their own phone on a real app, so it feels utterly fair.
Method: The secret is that the magician (or the app connected to their accounts) updates the prediction online in real time, moments before the reveal, or uses dual reality. With tools like Hydra by Shameer Salim, magicians already integrate secret information into social media profiles on the flyâ€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
. Hereâ€™s a likely workflow: The spectatorâ€™s choice is forced or obtained by the magician. The EchoMind app, integrated with social media APIs, then immediately posts or edits the predefined prediction to include that choice. Modern platforms like Instagram and Twitter allow editing profile info via third-party apps (with proper authentication). For a quicker result, the magicianâ€™s profile bio could have blank spaces or multiple outcomes pre-written (like â€œI knew youâ€™d pick ____â€) and the app simply fills in the blank or highlights the correct line. Another approach is to use a prepared â€œprediction postâ€ that isnâ€™t publicly visible until needed â€“ for example, a private post that is made public at the right time. The app could flip the privacy setting or share a previously hidden prediction when triggered. Since spectators typically wonâ€™t check the magicianâ€™s profile before the trick, this covert change goes unnoticed. If using something like Instagram Stories or Twitter, one can even exploit the timestamp â€“ e.g., a Twitter post timestamp might show it was posted 2 hours ago, but it was actually just posted (there are ways to fudge this by using scheduled posts or simply relying on the fact that laymen donâ€™t scrutinize the exact minutes). Regardless, when spectator B opens the social page, they see a legit page (not a fake website) with a prediction that appears to have been there all along. The combination of a real app and the permanence of social media sells it strongly.
Difficulty: 3/5 â€“ While the spectator handling is straightforward (they just navigate an app they know), the magician or the EchoMind app must be quick to update the prediction. Timing is key; you may need a moment of misdirection or a plausible reason to â€œcheck something on the phoneâ€ (if doing it manually). With automation, it can happen in a split second. Thereâ€™s also a risk factor: relying on live internet and third-party platforms means one must have contingency plans (like a backup reveal if the internet fails or the profile doesnâ€™t update in time).
Device Features: Internet connectivity, integration with Social Media APIs (Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, etc.), possibly automation/scripting to edit profile or post content. Also, two devices: the magicianâ€™s device to update, spectatorâ€™s device to verify.
Inspiration: This is inspired by the trend of magicians doing predictions via social media â€“ often called â€œFacebook or Instagram predictions.â€ Hydra, as mentioned, can take info from other apps and seamlessly turn it into a social media prediction in your bioâ€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
. David Copperfield once did a famous Twitter prediction for the Academy Awards. Our routine would make this accessible for close-up performers via an app. It builds on classic pre-show prediction ideas (like sealed envelopes that are opened to show a prediction) but uses a modern â€œsealed envelopeâ€ that everyone trusts: a timestamped social media post. The dual-device aspect (performer updating, spectator reading) keeps the performerâ€™s hands off the spectatorâ€™s phone, increasing the mystery. Essentially, itâ€™s leveraging the digital footprint as a stage for predictions, something underutilized and very strong when done rightâ€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
.

Each of these new trick ideas demonstrates how the EchoMind app could exploit smartphonesâ€™ rich features â€“ from sensors like accelerometers and light detectors to connectivity via web, SMS, and social media â€“ to create magic that feels unprecedented. By drawing inspiration from classic magic principles and modern tech-driven magic (like existing apps and effects), we ensure these routines are both innovative and grounded in proven concepts. The result is a suite of illusions and utilities that can astonish spectators and equip magicians with powerful new tools, all using the ubiquitous device in our pockets. Whether itâ€™s mentalism with a tech twist, visual impossibilities aided by AR and sensors, secret utilities that give magicians superhero-like abilities, or multi-device feats connecting people in impossible ways â€“ this collection covers it all, pushing the boundaries of phone-based magic.

Research completed in 12m Â· 23 sources
Modern magicians increasingly use smartphones and digital technology as props to create astonishing illusions. Phone-based magic bridges classic mentalism and cutting-edge tech: a spectatorâ€™s own phone can become a mind-reading device or a stage for visual miracles. This trend began with effects performed over phone calls (e.g. calling a stranger who reveals a chosen cardâ€‹
conjuror.community
) and has evolved into sophisticated smartphone apps and gadgets that achieve feats once impossible. Todayâ€™s digital magic ranges from simple app-based card tricks to elaborate multi-device routines that feel like technological â€œhackingâ€ of reality. Below, we explore a comprehensive spectrum of phone and digital magic techniques â€“ from psychological forces and camera tricks to NFC-powered miracles â€“ with descriptions, how theyâ€™re performed, and ideas for integrating each as a modular EchoMind component.
Before smartphones, magicians leveraged telephones and psychology for â€œmagic at a distance.â€ For example, the classic Wizard routine had an audience member dial a random number, only for the person on the other end to divine a secret choice. Modern versions like Jonathan Levitâ€™s The Stranger update this with cell phones â€“ a spectator calls a genuinely random number and the stranger who answers somehow knows their selected playing cardâ€‹
conjuror.community
â€‹
conjuror.community
. Early pioneers also developed verbal mentalism for radio and phone: Juan Tamarizâ€™s Verbal Magic and Patrick Redfordâ€™s Heptagon (a book of phone mentalism) taught performers to read minds over a telephone without visual cuesâ€‹
penguinmagic.com
â€‹
penguinmagic.com
. These routines relied on clever wordplay, psychological forcing, or secret confederates rather than electronics.
Psychological forcing has long been a staple â€“ such as subtly influencing a person to think of a specific number or word â€“ and it remains useful in digital contexts. A classic example is the â€œToxicâ€ calculator force, where a sequence of math operations inevitably leads to a predicted number. Newer tools like Chronoforce Pro cleverly use a phoneâ€™s stopwatch to force a number for predictions (from PIN codes to lottery results)â€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
. The methodology may be old, but performing it on a smartphone feels novel to audiences. EchoMind can incorporate these timeless techniques in a module that guides the magician through proven forcing scripts (text or audio) on calls or in person. For instance, an EchoMind â€œVerbal Forceâ€ module could prompt the performer with patter to ensure a target outcome (like a chosen number or card) without any app needed â€“ making classic mentalism easily accessible.
EchoMind integration: Classic phone tricks can be modernized by EchoMind as a â€œTelepathy Module.â€ This module would allow an EchoMind user to perform call-in tricks or verbal forces with guided scripts and even voice analysis. For example, EchoMind could have an automated phone-call system: the magician triggers a call to a preset â€œstrangerâ€ (an EchoMind service or confederate) who delivers a revelation on cue. Time-tested forces (like mathematical forces or word forces) could be built-in routines. This gives EchoMind users the ability to perform proven classics (like The Wizard call) by simply following on-screen instructions, while the heavy lifting (calling the number, or analyzing responses) is handled by the platform.
In the smartphone era, dedicated magic apps have unlocked powerful new mentalism feats. These apps often allow a magician to apparently read minds or predict choices using the spectatorâ€™s own phone, amplifying the impact. For instance, WikiTest by Marc Kerstein turns a spectatorâ€™s iPhone into a tool for a book test â€“ the spectator searches Wikipedia on their phone and the magician instantly knows what theyâ€™re readingâ€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
. Similarly, Greg Rostamiâ€™s Inject 2.0 is lauded as one of the most powerful magic apps, enabling the performer to secretly obtain anything searched on Google on the participantâ€™s deviceâ€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
. With that information, one can reveal a thought-of word, show a predicted image, find a chosen location on Maps, or even produce a custom video â€“ all seemingly impossible outcomesâ€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
. These apps exploit covert communication: the magician might have a second device or smartwatch receiving the data, or the app may use techniques like fake web pages and pre-loaded outcomes.
Other apps focus on forcing choices through digital means. Digital Force Bag (DFB), for example, is an app that mimics a notes or list app where a spectator scrolls a list and freely names an item next to any number â€“ yet it is always the force item the magician wantsâ€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
. All the dirty work happens behind the scenes on the phone, and even the spectator can scroll to the number themselvesâ€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
. Thereâ€™s also a pro version (DFB X) with more features, and tools like Inertia that allow forces on any website â€“ even on the spectatorâ€™s own phone in real timeâ€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
. This means a magician could have someone go to a random website and still control the outcome. Cognito (by Lloyd Barnes & Owen Garfield) took a different approach: it uses psychological and visual principles in an app such that the spectator never realizes theyâ€™ve given any information, yet the performer gains access to their thought-of number, image, or wordâ€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
. Cognito provides various presentations and lets magicians craft custom routines where the app does the secret data extraction, making it appear as pure mind-readingâ€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
.
Beyond pure mind-reading, some apps create elaborate prediction effects. The Stranger (mentioned above as a routine) is also facilitated by an app: Jonathan Levitâ€™s Stranger app will generate genuinely random phone numbers to call and can integrate with other apps like WikiTest or Inject, so that the person on the phone (a â€œstrangerâ€) can reveal not just a card, but any thought â€“ words, places, dates, etc.â€‹
vanishingincmagic.com
. This turns a simple card trick into an expansive revelation system. Another example is Hydra by Shameer Salim, which acts as a utility app to bridge information between services. Hydra can take a secret detail (say, a word a spectator looked up in WikiTest) and instantly post a prediction of it on the magicianâ€™s real Instagram or Facebook profileâ€‹

A card magic app forcing a playing card: Modern magic apps like Inject 2.0 and Digital Force Bag allow magicians to force choices or read minds using a borrowed smartphone. EchoMind could incorporate such app-driven forces as modules, letting users perform miracles with any phone.â€‹
